item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Begins Invasion From Land and Sea
item.description: Areas across Ukraine were under attack on Thursday morning. President Biden condemned President Vladimir Putin’s actions, saying he would speak to the American people on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Sergey Guneev/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin at the Kremlin in Moscow this month.

item.title: How China and Xi Jinping Have Turned on the Outside World
item.description: Global engagement has helped the nation prosper. But now, its leader seems intent on recasting the meeting of minds and cultures as a zero-sum clash.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, as seen on a giant screen outside a shopping mall in July 2021, speaking at an event to commemorate the 100th anniversary of China’s Communist Party.

item.title: Putin's Speech, Annotated: A Close Look at the Russian Leader's Ukraine Address
item.description: In an impassioned address about Ukraine, Russia’s leader laid bare grievances old and new. We took at look at what it might mean.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Alexey Nikolsky/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with members of Russia’s Security Council in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: The Limits of a Europe Whole and Free
item.description: Vladimir Putin sets down a marker in Ukraine. Does the West have the means to stop him?
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Russian self-propelled howitzers Msta-S are loaded onto a train car at the station outside Taganrog, Russia, on Tuesday.

item.title: How Colombian Feminists Decriminalized Abortion
item.description: As the United States faces growing restrictions on abortion, activists in Latin America are increasingly relying on one another to knock down barriers in the region.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abortion supporters celebrated on Monday in front of Colombia’s Constitutional Court in Bogotá during the ruling in favor of decriminalizing abortion in the first 24 weeks of pregnancy.

item.title: The Ukraine Crisis: What to Know About Why Russia Attacked
item.description: Here’s why Ukraine’s relevance extends far beyond its borders.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier this month in Luhansk Oblast, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: The Potentially Grim Fate of a Ukrainian Town Called ‘Happiness’
item.description: If Russia invades, military analysts say, the border settlement’s Russian-sympathizing citizenry and its prize power plant make it a likely starting point.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Shchastya collecting water from wells around the town on Wednesday after the town’s water and electricity supplies were knocked out by artillery.

item.title: New Zealand Antivaccine Protest Gets More Violent
item.description: An occupation in the capital demonstrates the dangerous influence that American disinformation is having on otherwise stable democracies.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:description: Demonstrators and the police outside of the Parliament grounds in Wellington, New Zealand, on Tuesday.

item.title: For Some in U.K., End of Covid Restrictions Threatens More Isolation
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson is abolishing Covid regulations to move “back towards normality.” But people at high risk from the disease say the move will constrict their lives instead.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Commuters in London on Tuesday. England ended its national mask mandate for public transit last month.

item.title: Covid Updates: Los Angeles County Lifts Mask Mandate in Public Indoor Spaces
item.description: The county, home to 10 million people, became one of the latest in the United States to ease restrictions. Sanofi and GSK said their vaccine is highly effective at protecting against severe disease.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Face masks being handed out at John F. Kennedy International Airport in December.

item.title: As French Elections Loom, Macron Tries to Strike a Balance
item.description: The news media calls the French president “Jupiter,” the king of the gods, but he is trying to show a more human face. Will it soften his image?
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, center left, at an Armistice Day event in Paris in November. The power of the presidency in the country has little equivalent in other Western democracies.

item.title: Climate Change Could Increase Risk of Wildfires 50% by Century's End
item.description: Worsening heat and dryness could lead to a 50 percent rise in off-the-charts fires, according to a United Nations report.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wildfire near Hillville, New South Wales, Australia, in 2019.

item.title: Rare Retrial Begins in Killing of American in Greece
item.description: Bakari Henderson, of Texas, was beaten to death in 2017. The men convicted in his case were found guilty of assault, but prosecutors are trying again with murder charges.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Police officers escorting two of the suspects in the killing of Bakari Henderson to a court in Patras, Greece, in January 2020.

item.title: Ukraine Enclaves Long Steeped in Conflict Face New Peril
item.description: A decision by Russia to recognize two separatist territories and order in troops raises the risks of intensified fighting in an already fraught region where violence has defined life for nearly a decade.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktoria Gudyatskaya and her daughter Svetlana, 14, boarding a train to Kyiv in Severodonetsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russia invades Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, spoke on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Vows to 'Hold Russia Accountable' and Congress Calls for Sanctions
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said the world would “hold Russia accountable” after explosions were seen in Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: Putin announces a ‘military operation’ in Ukraine as the U.N. Security Council pleads with him to pull back.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Putin Spins a Conspiracy Theory That Ukraine Is on a Path to Nuclear Weapons
item.description: Russia’s president has made such arguments before, but usually as asides — not as the justification for urgent action in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin has used recent speeches and public appearances to make a case for a Russian invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: New U.S. Sanctions Target Russian Company Behind Nord Stream 2
item.description: The move by President Biden came as administration officials warned that a Russian military assault on Ukraine could be imminent.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Facilities for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany. Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany announced on Tuesday that he would suspend the certification of the pipeline.

item.title: White House Prepares Curbs on Russia’s Access to U.S. Technology
item.description: Biden administration officials have warned Russia that it could face further restrictions on technology that is critical to its economy and military.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Wally Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, in November. Mr. Adeyemo said on Wednesday that the United States was coordinating closely with European allies on efforts to exert pressure on Russia’s economy.

item.title: Many Russians Feel a Deep Unease Over Going to War
item.description: After months of tuning out American warnings that Vladimir Putin was preparing to invade Ukraine, Russians now realize that “this is not a game.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The possibility of war was one of the greatest fears for Russians, many of whom dismissed it as an outlandish concoction until recently.

item.title: Iraj Pezeshkzad, Author of Classic Iranian Novel, Dies at 94
item.description: The satirical “My Uncle Napoleon” became a cultural touchstone that held up a mirror to his country, before the 1979 revolution sent the author into exile in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Rameshbabu Praggnanandhaa Defeats Chess World Champion Magnus Carlsen
item.description: While it did not affect the reigning champion’s title, Rameshbabu Praggnanandhaa of India defeated Carlsen in the middle of the night during a rapid online tournament, stunning the chess world.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Russian Mercenaries Covertly Entered Separatist Areas of Ukraine
item.description: Two senior European security officials say that the paramilitary fighters are inside the rebel territories of Ukraine to lay the groundwork for war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier after explosions hit near his unit’s position on Wednesday in Zaitseve, in the Luhansk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Ukraine’s State of Emergency
item.description: Bracing for war as Vladimir Putin appears undeterred by initial sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: On Eve of War, No Exodus From Ukraine, Only Anxiety and Disbelief
item.description: When Russian troops moved into eastern Ukraine, some began to travel westward, filled with doubt about the future but saying they planned — or hoped — to return.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers waited to board a train at the central train station in Kyiv on Tuesday.

item.title: What Russia's Conflict in Ukraine Means for the U.S. Economy
item.description: A Russian invasion of Ukraine could push up oil and food prices globally at a time of already-high inflation. In the U.S., it will drive up uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A forklift operator moved steel sheets at the Port of Mykolaiv. Ukraine is a significant producer of uranium, titanium, iron ore, steel and ammonia.

item.title: Moscow says separatist allies requested its help, and the U.S. says a Russian attack on Ukraine could be imminent.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Russian self-propelled howitzers Msta-S are loaded onto a train car at the station outside Taganrog, Russia, on Tuesday.

item.title: The U.S. is preparing a ban on American technology exports to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Wally Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, in November.

item.title: How Russian troops closed in on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Josh Holder, Allison McCann, Scott Reinhard and Michael Schwirtz

item.title: European Sanctions Target Putin’s Inner Circle
item.description: The measures, coinciding with new U.S. moves, were designed to hurt individuals but not average Russians. But more will follow if Russia fully invades Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: The Russian defense minister, Sergei Shoigu, in Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: Poland Will Lift Most Remaining Restrictions on March 1.
item.description: The move is a turnaround for the Eastern European nation, which was among a handful of countries in the region that were hit especially hard by earlier variants.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Tolek Magdziarz
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists on Dluga Street last summer in Gdansk, Poland.

item.title: Turkey, still recovering from pandemic lockdowns, is shocked by soaring electricity bills.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: A bar in Istanbul this month. The cost of power has doubled in some parts of Turkey, fueling widespread discontent.

item.title: Can Sanctions Work?
item.description: Yes, but they often don’t.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A power station in Luhansk burned after being bombed yesterday.

item.title: Some in Taiwan See Parallels to Ukraine
item.description: Some analysts worry that a weak global response to Ukraine could embolden China’s Communist Party to ramp up pressure on self-governed Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:description: Taiwanese soldiers during an urban warfare drill in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, in January.

item.title: Europe Prepares for Ukraine Refugees as Aid Groups Warn of Crisis
item.description: “If war breaks out, the consequences for the Ukrainian people — and for Europe — cannot be overstated,” said one humanitarian official.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A border crossing between Poland and Ukraine on Tuesday.

item.title: China Criticizes Sanctions Against Russia as Ineffective
item.description: Beijing said the penalties could hurt average people and its own interests.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, left, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: How Sanctions on Russia Could Affect Champions League and Top Soccer Clubs
item.description: The most vocal opposition has come from Britain, which could supply one or both of the final’s participants.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Last year’s final was contested between the Premier League teams Manchester City and Chelsea. The latter is owned by a Russian oligarch, Roman Abramovich.

item.title: Global leaders send a message with coordinated penalties.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Anton Troianovski, Austin Ramzy, Valerie Hopkins and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A global response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden condemned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Tuesday.

item.title: Ireland ends mask mandates in most places and social distancing in schools.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: A woman had her mask on her wrist as she drank coffee in Dublin in late January.

item.title: U.S. and Allies Impose Sanctions on Russia as Biden Condemns ‘Invasion’ of Ukraine
item.description: President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that more sanctions would follow if he did not withdraw his forces and engage in diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Richard Pérez-Peña, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parents said goodbye to their children in Severodonetsk, eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday, after President Vladimir V. Putin recognized separatist areas of the country.

item.title: New satellite images show military deployments continuing along the Ukrainian border.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl

item.title: Will Biden’s Sanctions Halt a Russian Invasion of Ukraine?
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin has learned from earlier U.S.-led sanctions, and his allies could benefit from a more isolated Russia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin has had years to make his country’s $1.5 trillion economy more insular so that parts of Russia would be shielded from tough penalties.

item.title: UN Leader Deepens Criticism of Russia Over Ukraine Crisis
item.description: António Guterres said Ukraine’s sovereign territory had been violated, and he rejected Vladimir Putin’s description of Russian troops as peacekeepers.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: António Guterres, the secretary general of the United Nations, at the U.N. headquarters in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Here Is a Transcript of President Biden’s Speech on Russia
item.description: Here is a lightly edited transcript of the president’s speech announcing new sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. moves warplanes and more troops to Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: American soldiers at the Fort Bragg Army Post in North Carolina before being deployed to Eastern Europe this month.

item.title: Videos show burning of documents in a Russian consulate in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Evan Hill, Brenna Smith and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: Blinken cancels meeting with his Russian counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley

item.title: Ukraine’s president calls up reserves, urging his compatriots to fight for their country.
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky said his government would work to “raise the preparedness of the Ukrainian army to all possible changes in the operational situation.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian reservists in Kyiv, Ukraine, last December.

item.title: Trump Refers to Russian Aggression Toward Ukraine as ‘Genius’
item.description: In a radio interview, the former president also described Russian troops along the Ukrainian border as peacekeepers.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Osaka, Japan, in 2019.

item.title: Russia’s Moves in Ukraine Unsettle Energy Companies and Prices
item.description: Oil and gas prices are up, and Western energy giants with operations and investments in Russia could find it harder to keep doing business there.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed
item.media:description: A power station in eastern Ukraine was heavily bombed on Tuesday. Oil prices quickly jumped to nearly $100 a barrel after reports that Russian troops had entered Ukrainian separatist territories.

item.title: In Kyiv, a Soldier’s Funeral and Vows of Defiance
item.description: Ukrainians have been preparing for a possible military escalation by Russia for months. They were somber but largely defiant.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral on Tuesday for Capt. Anton Sidorov, a 35-year-old Ukrainian intelligence officer killed three days earlier while serving on the front line in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: The West Sanctions Russia
item.description: President Biden condemned what he called the “beginning of a Russian invasion of Ukraine.”
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden spoke on Tuesday about tensions between Russia and Ukraine.
